title: Does causal determinism undermine free will and moral responsibility? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, because free will and moral responsibility are not metaphysical questions. If indeterminism were true, all your actions and decisions would be random and purposeless, and your mind would be too incoherent to be a “mind” in the first place. Free will is just a shorthand for human agency, exercised without undue coercion or pressure. It’s a description of what people do, not a metaphysic. So the question is a Philosophy 101 category error.

Free will? Depends how you see it. Responsibility? No. Even if, like me, you consider human brains to be like computers with personalities as programs, you can still see the purpose in improving those programs and culling the most destructive units. And the fact that you couldn't change the inputs does not mean that you aren't responsible for the way you process those signals and generate output. If the power goes out and it turns out the transformer (trash can looking thing on the pole) blew, the transformer is responsible for the power going out and it gets replaced. Some blame may also go to those who designed and installed the transformer, but that doesn't change that the transformer is ultimately what failed.

Yes. I am among those, like Robert Kane, Isaiah Berlin, Karl Popper, and William James, who believe both the following propositions: as a matter of fact human actions are not fully determined, because nothing is fully determined — even the most ironclad laws of nature may prove to be probabilistic in time andwe should he grateful that this is so, for intuitively appealing ideas of free will and moral responsibility are incompatible with any thorough determinism.This is the in-in view (both incompatibilist and indeterminist). For further discussion, I would refer you to the pertinent works of the four authors I just named. Begin with this one: Isaiah Berlin - Historical Inevitability

Yes it does,free will is a myth and moral responsibility is the result of a cognitive chemical function that has evolved over many years the beginning of which had to be for it to develop. It is so simple that it sounds complicated.

Maybe, if you choose to believe that causal determinism is valid. You can choose to hold the door for someone or choose to slam it in their face, and each choice will bear a different moral consequence, respectively.

Humans are agents. Objects and objects. The laws of physics that say help us understand dominoes and billard balls, don’t assume human free will and agency. We have empirical experience of free will—of making decisions. The assumption that we are just robots, undermine everything that Western civilization stands for including truth, human dignity, freedom, and justice.
No, because there is no such thing as causal determinism in reality. Instead, we do have free will and moral responsibility.
